Award.AwardTitle: Search for Dark Matter with XENON100
Award.AbstractNarration:
There is ample evidence that large amounts of matter in the Universe are made from an unknown kind, called Dark Matter. Yet, its properties are largely unknown and pose a major challenge for contemporary physics. The XENON100 collaboration, working at the underground laboratory at Gran Sasso, Italy, runs the currently most sensitive experiment to search for Dark Matter. Together with the large volume and mass of the detector, the low background enables studies of the nature of Dark Matter that are not possible with any other operating detector.

This award provides base support to work on the unique opportunities that data from the XENON100 detector provide to search for signatures that are expected from unconventional models of Dark Matter particles. The data will be studied in original analyses to gain new insights into the nature of Dark Matter. Two different and dedicated searches will be performed for Dark Matter particles with low masses. Innovative searches for signals that are predicted by models such as inelastic Dark Matter or magnetic inelastic Dark Matter will be carried out.

Broader impacts: the PI will continue to build on previous experience from his involvement in a planetarium and other outreach activities in order to stimulate the imagination and curiosity of the public. Newspaper articles and other channels of diverse popular science communication will be utilized to disseminate results from the research. Undergraduate and graduate students as well as a postdoctoral researcher will be educated and trained in research at the cutting edge of modern astroparticle physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overwhelming astronomical and cosmological evidence supports a self-consistent model of the Universe where five times more matter than known matter is in the unknown form of Dark Matter. Discovery of the nature of Dark Matter is internationally recognized as one of the greatest challenges in science, fundamental to our understanding of the Universe. So far, no direct evidence has been found for Dark Matter particles.

The most compelling candidate for Dark Matter is a Weakly Interacting Massive Particle (WIMP) that arises naturally in several models of physics beyond the Standard Model of particle physics. As we move with Earth through our Galaxy, we encounter a flux of these particles that creates the possibility to directly detect WIMPs in a laboratory target. Given the crucial importance of this topic, the direct detection of Dark Matter is currently an extremely active and competitive area of research. Globally, more than a dozen experiments, utilizing a variety of different technologies, aim to push their sensitivities to the required levels.

The most promising and most cost-effective technology seems to be dual-phase time-projection chambers (TPCs) using liquid noble elements.Those employing liquid xenon in particular are leading this international scientific endeavor. The XENON100 detector measures 30cm in both diameter and height and contains 62kg of liquid xenon. The XENON1T detector measures 100cm in both height and diameter and contains 2000kg of liquid xenon in the instrumented volume. These massive targets efficiently reduce the background from external radiation sources and provide an inner fiducial target volume with unprecedented low levels of background radiation in the low-energy range. These detectors represent the most sensitive machines ever built to detect WIMP Dark Matter.

This grant supported the participation of the Purdue group in the international XENON100 and XENON1T collaborations. In particular, funding was provided to use these detectors to search for somewhat non-traditional Dark Matter signals. As the commonly expected Dark Matter signals have not yet been observed, the Purdue group was extending the capabilities of these detectors to different Dark Matter signatures. A search for so-called spin-dependent WIMP interactions was conducted by the collaboration, as was a search for the so-called Axion particles interacting with the detector. We have established a collaboration with nuclear physics experts to lay the groundwork that enabled a sensitive search for Dark Matter that scatters inelastically off the xenon nuclei.

The XENON100 detector features an extremely low background from other kinds of radioactivity. Consequently, we were able to search all XENON100 low-energy data for signatures of Dark Matter. In particular, this included a search for so-called leptophilic Dark Matter particles. No such events have been found. This line of work culminated in the publication of two papers in the journals Science and Physical Review Letters, detailing these results.

A second line of work was in establishing a xenon laboratory at Purdue University. Through heavy involvement of more than 60 undergraduate students, this grant supported the successful commissioning of a fully operational liquid xenon detector laboratory. The lab is used to advance this detector technology further and serves as a training ground for undergraduate students in a wide array of relevant techniques.

The PI gave outreach talks at all regular outreach venues in the Lafayette area and was featured or interviewed by numerous national and
international media outlets. Together with tours of the Purdue laboratory, the PI directly reached more than 1500 individuals in face-to-face meetings and engaged in lectures, talks, conversations and discussions.
